Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 1
Science.text: The human eye uses light and enables us to see objects around us. What is the function of the lens in a human eye? How do the lenses used in spectacles correct defects of vision? We have lear nt in the pr evious chapter about light and some of its properties. In this chapter , we shall use these ideas to study some of the optical phenomena in natur e. We shall also discuss about rainbow formation, splitting of white light and blue colour of the sky.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 2
Science.text: The eye lens is composed of a fibrous, jelly-like material. Its curvature can be modified to some extent by the ciliary muscles. When the muscles are relaxed, the lens becomes thin. Thus, its focal length increases. This enables us to see distant objects clearly. To see an object comfortably and distinctly, you must hold it at about 25 cm from the eyes. The farthest point upto which the eye can see objects clearly is called the far point of the eye. It is infinity for a nor mal eye.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 3
Science.text: Explain the following concept in simple spoken-style English, as if in a classroom. Use short sentences, give one example, and end with a recap. The Human Eye and the Colour ful W orld 163(a) Myopia Myopia is also known as near - sightedness. A person with this defect has the far point nearer than infinity. Such a person may see clearly upto a distance of a few metres. In a myopic eye, the image of a distant object is formed in front of the retina. This defect can be corrected by using a concave lens of suitable power.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 4
Science.text: Do you know that our eyes can live even after our death? By donating our eyes after we die, we can light the life of a blind person. Eye donors can belong to any age group or sex. People who use spectacles, or those operated for cataract, can still donate the eyes. Diabetes, hypertension, asthma patients and those without communicable diseases can also donate eyes. These days, it is possible to correct the refractive defects with contact lenses or through surgical interventions.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 5
Science.text: Eyes must be removed within 4-6 hours after death. An eye bank collects, evaluates and distributes the donated eyes. Those donated eyes found unsuitable for transplantation are used for valuable research and medical education. One pair of eyes gives vision to up to FOUR CORNEAL BLIND PEOPLE. Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 7
Science.text: The prism has probably split the incident white light into a band of colours. The band of the coloured components of a light beam is called its spectrum. Different colours of light bend through different angles with respect to the incident ray, as they pass through a prism. The red light bends the least while the violet the most. It is the band of distinct colours that we see in a spectrum. A rainbow is a natural spectrum appearing in the sky after a rain shower (Fig. 10.7). It is caused by dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets, present in the atmosphere.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 8
Science.text: The twinkling of a star is due to atmospheric refraction of starlight. The starlight, on entering the earth’s atmosphere, undergoes refraction continuously before it reaches the earth. Since the atmosphere bends starlight towards the normal, the apparent position of the star is slightly different from its actual position. As the path of rays of light coming from the star goes on varying, its apparent position fluctuates. The amount of star light entering the eye flickers – the star sometimes appears brighter , and at some othethe.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 9
Science.text: Explain the following concept in simple spoken-style English, as if in a classroom. Use short sentences, give one example, and end with a recap. The Human Eye and the Colour ful W orld 16910.6 SC ATTERING OF LIGHT. The interplay of light with objects around us gives rise to several spectacular phenomena in nature. The blue colour of the sky, colour of water in deep sea, the reddening of the sun at sunrise and the sunset are some of the wonderful phenomena we are familiar with.

Science.title: Lesson 10 - Part 10
Science.text: The ability of the eye to focus on both near and distant objects, by adjusting its focal length, is called the accommodation of theEye. The smallest distance, at which the eye can see objects clearly without strain, is known as the near point. For a young adult with normal vision, it is about 25 cm. The splitting of white light into its component colours is called dispersion. Scattering of light causes the blue colour of the sky. Make a diagram to show how hypermetropia is corrected.
